row.entry: This Division deals with the procedures for giving evidence in interlocutory proceedings and at trials. It includes provisions relating to witness statements, Evidence Act notices, the use of foreign material, plans and models, evidence given on other occasions and the production and proof of court documents.

entry.emph: Division 2 — Provisions applicable to expert evidence generally — Rules 31.17–31.54

row.entry: This Division relates to the use of expert evidence and includes provisions regulating the appointment and engagement of expert witnesses, content and service of experts’ reports, conferences between expert witnesses, parties’ single experts and court-appointed experts.

This Part does not apply to the Local Court, Small Claims Division. Divisions 1 and 2 do not apply in the Industrial Relations Commission (when constituted otherwise than as the Industrial Court) except for rr 31.1–31.4, 31.11–31.12, 31.16A: see r 1.5 and Sch 1 . Rules 31.7, 31.11, 31.12, 31.21 and 31.22 apply to criminal proceedings in the Supreme Court: SCA Third Schedule and SCR Pt 75 r 3 and r 6.
Rules 31.7, 31.11 , 31.12 , 31.21 and 31.22 apply to criminal proceedings in the Supreme Court: SCA Third Schedule and SCR Pt 75 r 3 and r 6.

The Part is based on the former Federal Court Rules, Order 34A, rule 3 , SCR Pts 36 and 39, DCR Pts 28 and 28A and LCR Pts 23, 25 and 38B. Two significant changes are introduced by the UCPR. First, the District Court requirement that places the onus on the party seeking to cross-examine an expert to procure that expert’s attendance is now the common procedure: see UCPR r 31.30(3) . Second, the Federal Court Rules regarding the concurrent or hot-tubbing procedure for experts to give evidence has been adopted: see UCPR r 31.30 . Division 2 commenced on 8 December 2006 in response to the NSW LRC Report 109 “Expert witnesses”, June 2006.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.1] r 31.1 Manner of giving evidence at trial (cf SCR Part 36, rule 2; DCR Part 28, rule 2; LCR Part 25, rule 9)

leg:heading.title: Manner of giving evidence at trial (cf SCR Part 36, rule 2; DCR Part 28, rule 2; LCR Part 25, rule 9)

p.text: This rule applies to a trial of proceedings commenced by statement of claim, or in which a statement of claim has been filed.
Subject to subrules (3), (4) and (5) and to the provisions of the Evidence Act 1995, a witness’s evidence at a trial must be given orally before the court.
[subr (2) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[32], effective 15 August 2005]
The court may order that all or any of a witness’s evidence at a trial must be given by affidavit or, subject to rule 31.4, by witness statement.
Unless the court orders otherwise, evidence of facts must be given by affidavit if the only matters in question are:
interest up to judgment in respect of a debt or liquidated claim, or
the assessment of damages or the value of goods under Part 30, or
costs.
Unless the court otherwise orders, at any trial on an assessment of the amount to be recovered by a plaintiff after default judgment has been given, the following evidence may be given by affidavit:
evidence of the identity of any motor vehicle,
evidence of the damage sustained by a motor vehicle in a particular collision,
evidence of the reasonable cost of repairing that damage.
[subr (5) insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[32], effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [31.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 24.3.

The present rule deals with the usual procedure at hearings. It needs to be understood in the light of the courts’ extensive directions powers — in ss 61 and 62 of the CPA and rr 2.1 and 2.3 of the CP Rules. Regard is also required to be had to the directions powers in r 29.5 and the usual course of evidence provided for in r 29.6 of the CP Rules. See also UCPR r 24.3 for the giving of evidence otherwise than in a trial.

The present rule permits the court to order that a witness’ evidence in chief be given by affidavit or evidence in chief. Evidence provided in this form can significantly contribute to both the fairness and the efficiency of the proceedings. But there are potential limits on the extent to which evidence in this form is desirable. Where there are disputed issues of fact involving oral representations and conversations, affidavit evidence can sometimes be an unsatisfactory medium for leading the evidence-in-chief. Both affidavits and witness statements are likely to have contentious conversations and communications being expressed in language that has been settled, ordered and edited with substantial input from others, particularly legal advisers. As a result, the contents of this kind of written evidence may be unreliable and unintentionally misleading. The witness’ frank and honest recollection of the communication, given orally in the witness box without the formality of an affidavit or the “supervising hand of an interested lawyer” might be more reliable: Thomas v SMP (International) Pty Ltd [2010] NSWSC 822; BC201005238 at [23]–[29] (extremely lengthy affidavit — extensive objections — affidavit rejected): see also “Practical Litigation in the Federal Court of Australia — Affidavits” (2001) 20 Australian Bar Review 28.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.2] r 31.2 Evidence of witnesses at other hearings (cf SCR Part 36, rule 3; DCR Part 28, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Evidence of witnesses at other hearings (cf SCR Part 36, rule 3; DCR Part 28, rule 3)

p.text: Subject to rule 31.1, evidence in chief of any witness at any hearing must be given by affidavit unless the court orders otherwise.
[r 2 am Amendment 4 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[8], effective 11 November 2005]

level.toc-caption: [31.2.5] Affidavit evidence — all hearings other than trials in proceedings commenced by statement of claim

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.1.

heading.title: Affidavit evidence — all hearings other than trials in proceedings commenced by statement of claim

p.text: The rule requires that evidence in chief at all hearings, other than trials in proceedings commenced by statement of claim (to which r 31.1 applies) will normally be given by affidavit. The rule applies to all interlocutory proceedings and to the final hearing of proceedings commenced by summons. The use of affidavit evidence encourages earlier disclosure of the apparent strength of the opposing contentions, identification of the real points of dispute and a reduction in court hearing time. The court retains a discretion to permit oral evidence in an appropriate case — such as where a proposed witness will not voluntarily provide an affidavit or statement (see [31.4.15] or where particular credibility issues arise that are best tested by oral evidence. The general requirement for evidence to be given by affidavit does not preclude supplementary oral evidence adduced to overcome objections to the form of affidavit evidence.

Section 75 of the Evidence Act 1995 provides that the hearsay rule does not apply to interlocutory proceedings if the source of the evidence is given. The section does not explicitly require the deponent to aver to belief in the truth of the hearsay information but the general provisions of the Evidence Act in relation to the manner in which evidence may be given (see for example, ss 13 and 21) require truthful evidence. Consequently either the deponent’s belief in the truth of the hearsay information may be implied, or the weight of the proferred evidence is liable to be discounted: Chapmans Ltd v Davey (NSWSC, Bryson J, No 2856/93, 27 April 1998, unreported, BC9801396). However, care should be taken to determine whether the evidence tendered is, in truth, hearsay in relation to the issue in question. For example, in applications for the extension of the limitation period under the Limitation Act 1969, material which goes to show the availability of evidence to support the substantive cause of action may be admissible even though it would constitute hearsay if it was tendered as part of the proof of the cause of action itself: Martin v Abbott Australasia Pty Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 430 at 443 ; Baker v Australian Asbestos Insulations Pty Ltd [1984] 3 NSWLR 595 . Similarly, on an application for an interlocutory injunction, evidence which bears upon the capacity of a party to prove a particular fact may be admissible as tending to show the existence of a real question to be tried, even though the material would not be admissible at the final hearing as evidence of the truth of the fact asserted: Geoffrey W Hill & Associates v King (1992) 27 NSWLR 228 . In an interlocutory proceeding in which a contested claim of client legal privilege arises evidence relating to substantiation of claim is not restricted to the evidence in admissible form: Re Southland Coal Pty Ltd (rec & mgrs apptd) (in liq) (2006) 59 ACSR 87; [2006] NSWSC 899; BC200606961 at [21]–[26] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.3] r 31.3 Evidence by telephone, video link or other communication (cf SCR Part 36, rule 2A; DCR Part 28, rule 2A; LCR Part 23, rule 1C)

leg:heading.title: Evidence by telephone, video link or other communication (cf SCR Part 36, rule 2A; DCR Part 28, rule 2A; LCR Part 23, rule 1C)

p.text: If the court so orders, evidence and submissions may be received by telephone, video link or other form of communication.
This rule does not apply to circumstances in which directions could be sought under section 25 of the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 of the Commonwealth.

The present rule is complemented by several statutory provisions (the Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 and Pt 4 of the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Cth)) and by the court’s incidental power to control its own procedure: Sunstate Airlines (Qld) Pty Ltd v First Chicago Australia Securities Ltd (NSWSC, Giles CJ Comm D, 11 March 1997, unreported, BC9700538); and to confer on the court broad discretionary powers to permit evidence to be given by audio/audio visual transmission. The Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 permits (without restricting the court’s other discretionary powers) evidence to be given by audio/audio visual transmission in any proceedings unless doing so would be less convenient than attendance at court or would be unfair to a party: see s 5B. If the place where the evidence is to be given is not in a “participating State” and the court ought not make a contested order unless the applicant satisfies the court that the order is in the interests of the administration of justice: see ss 5B(3) and 7 of that Act: see [31.3.10] . Where they are unlikely to attend unless compelled, it will be necessary either to subpoena the witness (if they are located in Australia or New Zealand) or to invoke the letter of request procedures considered in Evidence on Commission Act 1995: see r 24.5 (if the witness is located in another country: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2004) 49 ACSR 578; 22 ACLC 1125; [2004] NSWSC 467; BC200403134 ).

Although s 5B of the Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 permits the court to act on its own motion in some cases, a contested direction can only be made if the court is satisfied either that the interests of justice so require, or that the order is appropriate and not unfair to any party: see ss 5B(3) and 7 of that Act; Markisic v United States of America [2006] NSWSC 839; BC200606376 at [8] (telephone evidence of uncontentious expert). In practical terms, therefore, a moving party bears the onus of showing the appropriateness of making an order for evidence to be given by audio/audiovisual transmission: Australian Medical Imaging Pty Ltd v Marconi Medical Systems Australia Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 1 . Factors relevant to the exercise of the discretion to permit video/audio link testimony under this rule will include not only the nature of the evidence and the extent to which it is likely to be disputed, but also practical matters including the cost, convenience and duration of any proposed evidence: Markisic v United States of America [2006] NSWSC 839; BC200606376 . Where the application involves expert evidence it will also be relevant to consider the practical implications of the requirement for a joint expert conference and report: King v Rail Corporation of NSW [2012] NSWSC 832; BC201205416 at [12].

The centrality of the proposed evidence is not necessarily conclusive against an order being made, but when combined with the prospect of lengthy cross-examination, and a significant credit challenge, the court is likely to require the witness to attend the hearing in the absence of significant countervailing considerations: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2004) 49 ACSR 578; [2004] NSWSC 467; BC200403134 ; Poschung v Jones (NSWSC, Levine J, 25 October 1996, unreported, BC9606849) at p 8. In that regard the reported cases exhibit a range of judicial views about the general desirability of a witness’ physical presence at the hearing and the risk that court’s ability to assess a witness’ credibility may be undermined where evidence is given by audiovisual transmission.

In some cases judges have regarded audiovisual evidence as equivalent to ordinary testimony given in court: B v Dentists Disciplinary Tribunal [1994] 1 NZLR 95 ; Studniberg v JP Morgan Australia Ltd (1998) 84 IR 86; [1998] NSWIRComm 483 ; McDonald v Cmr of Taxation (2000) 44 ATR 226; 2000 ATC 4271; [2000] FCA 577; BC200002170 ; Tetra Pak Marketing Pty Ltd v Musashi Pty Ltd [2000] FCA 1261; BC200005376 . In other cases judges have been more willing to recognise that the procedure of giving evidence by audio visual transmission may involve a risk of diminishing the court's ability to accurately assess the quality and credibility of the evidence: K v S (2001) 27 Fam LR 498; 161 FLR 71 (whole of the proceedings); Sunstate Airlines (Qld) Pty Ltd v First Chicago Australia Securities Ltd (NSWSC, Giles CJ Comm D, 11 March 1997, unreported, BC9700538); Lamesa Holdings BV v Cmr of Taxation (FCA, Sackville J, No 978/97, 30 July 1998, unreported, BC9803928); Asermeley-Rivera v Neffati [2001] NSWSC 262; BC200101619 ; Australian Medical Imaging Pty Ltd v Marconi Medical Systems Australia Pty Ltd , above; Australian Competition and Consumer Commission v World Netsafe Pty Ltd (2002) 119 FCR 303; [2002] FCA 526; BC200202278 ; Moyette Pty Ltd v Foundation Healthcare Ltd [2003] FCA 116; BC200300493 .

A middle ground approach is to refrain from expressing any opinion as to whether evidence given in person is inherently preferable and to consider the suitability of the proposed audiovisual evidence in the light of the particular circumstances of each case: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich , above. In that context, the likelihood of extensive documentary cross-examination may provide a sufficient justification for refusing an application to adduce evidence by audio visual transmission: Cigna Insurance Australia Ltd v CSR Ltd (NSWSC, Rolfe J, 10 November 1995, unreported, BC9501624); Reinsurance Australia Corp Ltd v HIH Casualty & General Insurance Ltd (in liq) [2002] FCA 1549; BC200207544 ; Moyette Pty Ltd v Foundation Healthcare Ltd , above; Sheldon & Hammond Pty Ltd v Metrokane Inc [2002] FCA 1561; BC200207746 (application allowed where witness too ill to attend); Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich , above (prolonged documentary cross-examination and different time zones between court and witness — application refused).
Legislation cited in [31.3.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 75 r 3, SCR Pt 75 r 3(4).
(NSW) Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 s 5BA.

Rule 31.3 applies to criminal proceedings specified in the Third Schedule of the SCA (except cl (d) of that Schedule) and to proceedings in summary jurisdiction (Div 2 of Pt 75 of the SCR): SCR Pt 75 r 3(4) . Evidence by telephone, video link or other form of communication may not be ordered in respect of evidence given by an accused or where the order would prevent an accused from attending any part of proceedings, without the consent of that accused: see SCR Pt 75 r 3 . In addition, s 5BA of the Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 requires detainees to appear physically at any substantive trial or hearing, at any hearing to determine fitness to plead, on their first bail application before the court and on their first appearance in relation to an alleged offence and by audio visual link (if available) on any second or subsequent appearance unless the court otherwise directs in the interests of the administration of justice.
Practice Note SC Gen 15 establishes arrangements for the use of audio-visual links in criminal and certain civil proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.4] r 31.4 Court may direct party to furnish witness statement (cf SCR Part 36, rule 4A)

leg:heading.title: Court may direct party to furnish witness statement (cf SCR Part 36, rule 4A)

p.text: The court may direct any party to serve on each other active party a written statement of the oral evidence that the party intends to adduce in chief on any questions of fact to be decided at any hearing (a witness statement).
A direction under subrule (1):
may make different provision with regard to different questions of fact or different witnesses, and
may require that notice be given of any objection to any of the evidence in a witness statement and of the grounds of any such objection.
Each witness statement must be signed by the intended witness unless the signature of the witness cannot be procured or the court orders otherwise.
If an intended witness to whose evidence a witness statement relates does not give evidence, no party may put the statement in evidence at the hearing except by leave of the court.
If the party serving the statement calls as a witness at the hearing any person whose witness statement has been served pursuant to a direction under subrule (1):
that person’s witness statement is to stand as the whole of his or her evidence in chief, so long as that person testifies to the truth of the statement, and
except by leave of the court, the party may not adduce from that person any further evidence in chief.
A party who fails to comply with a direction given under this rule may not adduce evidence to which the direction relates, except by leave of the court.
This rule does not deprive any party of the right to treat any communication as privileged and does not make admissible any evidence that is otherwise inadmissible.

An application by a party for an order that the party not be required to comply with a direction under this rule in respect of any proposed witness or witnesses (whether or not such a direction has been given) may be made without serving notice of motion.

Both the present rule and UCPR r 2.3(k) permit the court to direct the provision of witness statements. In addition to these specific rules, general provisions regarding the use of witness statements may be contained in the Practice Notes that apply in a particular court. For example, in the Supreme Court, proceedings in the Commercial List and the Technology and Construction List are governed by Practice Note SC Eq 3 and in particular the Usual Order for Hearing (which is set out in Annexure 3 to the Note in Vol 2) at [SC Eq 3] . This requires that witness statements and experts’ reports be exchanged between the parties at least 28 days before the proceedings. Where the proceedings are in the Common Law Division (other than proceedings for defamation) Practice Note SC CL 5 applies. Under that Note directions may be given at the call over of proceedings requiring the filing of witness statements. Common Law proceedings (other than proceedings for defamation, or proceedings commenced outside Sydney) that are commenced by statement of claim, or in which the plaintiff claims damages or possession of land, or which have been transferred to the Common Law Division from another Division of the Court, are subject to differential case management, to which the provisions of Practice Note SC CL 5 apply.

level.toc-caption: [31.4.10] Default — reliance upon additional statements or evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.4.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 15.12(2)(b), 20.10.

heading.title: Default — reliance upon additional statements or evidence

p.text: Failure to comply with the requirements of the rules in relation to service of witness statements may lead to rejection of the evidence either under the present rule or pursuant to an order under s 61(3) of the CPA. But in either case the exercise of the discretion (to grant leave or to reject the evidence) requires compliance with the “dictates of justice” and consideration of the criteria in s 58(2) of the CPA. The general principles involved in the application of those criteria are discussed in notes [s 58.5] to [s 58.35] . Consistent with those principles the proper exercise of the relevant discretion will be significantly influenced by the nature and extent of any non-compliance, the stage of the proceedings when any leave is sought, the circumstances that lead to the non-compliance — or that gave rise to the need for additional evidence — and the risk of prejudice to the other party. As a general proposition leave should normally be given, or alternatively time for service extended, where the non-compliance occurs in the usual scope of the ordinary exigencies of preparing a matter for hearing. However, gross delay, repeated non-compliance, or belated reliance on material evidence, may justifiably result in the refusal of leave and the rejection of evidence: Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379; 104 ALR 165 ; GSA Industries Pty Ltd v NT Gas Ltd (1990) 24 NSWLR 710 ; State Pollution Control Commission v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 487; 75 LGERA 327; BC9203134 . This is especially so if the introduction of the new material would either entitle the opposing party to an adjournment (Government Insurance Office (NSW) v Best (1993) Aust Torts Reports ¶81-210 (failure to serve medical reports within the time required by the rules)); expose an opposing party to the risk of material prejudice as a result of continuing the hearing without adequate opportunity to evaluate and test the additional evidence; or deal with matters that were already within the scope of the existing evidence: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich [2005] NSWSC 706; BC200505178 (rejection of additional expert report intended to address rejection of parts of previous expert’s report). See also rr 15.12(2)(b) , 20.10 .

level.toc-caption: [31.4.15] Inability to obtain witness statement or affidavits

heading.title: Inability to obtain witness statement or affidavits

p.text: Where a party knows that a witness will not provide a witness statement or execute an affidavit, the convenient practice is for the party proposing to call the witness to provide an outline of the evidence expects that the witness will give. The notice should be as full as practicability, and available information, permit. Even where the outline is reasonably full and has been prepared in good faith, there is still potential for the witness to deviate from the outline at the hearing. There are practical reason why this may be anticipated. For example, the very process of leading evidence orally is likely to result in the witness giving evidence using different language, to different effect, and in a different order, than a previous outline. Where departure from the outline gives rise to a real risk of prejudice to another party an application may be made either to exclude the evidence or to seek an adjournment to meet it. In such a case the court's task is to weigh up the risk of prejudice to one party against the disadvantage to the other party if the new evidence is excluded. Provided the outline provided was a full and genuine attempt to notify the other parties of the proposed evidence the risk of surprise (at least in the absence of demonstrable prejudice) is not a ground for preventing or limiting the witness's evidence”: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Vines (2003) 21 ACLC 159; [2002] NSWSC 1223; BC200207912 at [8], [17] .

level.toc-caption: [31.4.20] Privilege and disclosure in relation to witness statements

heading.title: Privilege and disclosure in relation to witness statements

p.text: Privilege attaches to confidential witness statements that have been prepared for the dominant purpose of litigation: Esso Australia Resources Ltd v FCT (1999) 201 CLR 49; 168 ALR 123; [1999] HCA 67; BC9908417 overruling, Grant v Downs (1976) 135 CLR 674 at 682; 11 ALR 577; BC7600095 ; Attorney-General (NT) v Maurice (1986) 161 CLR 475 at 490; 69 ALR 31 ; Complete Technology Pty Ltd v Toshiba (Aust) Pty Ltd (1994) 53 FCR 125; 124 ALR 493; BC9405908 ; J-Corp Pty Ltd v Australian Builders’ Labourers’ Federated Union of Workers (WA) (No 1) (1992) 38 FCR 452; 110 ALR 510 (witness statements of non-parties). Use of a witness statement, including an expert’s report, will waive privilege (unless the disclosure can be regarded as made under compulsion of law): Manly Municipal Council v Ward (NSWCA, Powell and Stein JJA, 12 May 1997, unreported, BC9701836). Waiver may even occur when a witness is provided with a copy of a statement, unless the confidentiality of the document is expressly preserved: Newcastle Wallsend Coal Co Pty Ltd v Court of Coal Mines Regulation (1997) 42 NSWLR 351; BC9704259 ; Drabsch v Switzerland General Insurance Co Ltd [1999] NSWSC 975; BC9906285 . However, a waiver of privilege in relation to the statement itself, will not necessarily waive privilege in relation to prior communications with the witness. Privilege will continue to attach to confidential communications between a party and their lawyer. If the witness is not a party then the question whether privilege attaches to the prior communications depends upon establishing that the communications were confidential so far as that particular witness was concerned: Ritz Hotel Ltd v Charles of the Ritz Ltd (No 22) (1988) 14 NSWLR 132 ; Trade Practices Commission v Ampol Petroleum (Vic) Pty Ltd (1994) 52 FCR 578; 126 ALR 111 at 116 .

Voluntary disclosure of witness statements results in the loss of the privilege that would otherwise apply: Complete Technology Pty Ltd v Toshiba (Aust) Pty Ltd (1994) 53 FCR 125; 124 ALR 493; BC9405908 . But if the witness statements are served in compliance with the rules of court or specific pre-trial directions, the balance of authority favours the view that service is for the limited purpose (of preserving the serving party’s option to adduce the evidence at the trial) and does not waive privilege in the contents of the statement, either for the purpose of the current proceeding: Polyaire Pty Ltd v K-Aire Pty Ltd (2003) 226 LSJS 109; [2003] SASC 41; BC200301806 ; or subsequent proceedings: Smoothdale No 2 Ltd v State Bank of South Australia (1995) 54 SASR 224; 180 LSJS 126 (privilege not waived); Sevic v Roarty (1998) 44 NSWLR 287 (privilege not waived); Dubbo City Council v Barrett [2003] NSWCA 267; BC200305990 (report privileged from production to co-defendant, despite r 31.18); Akins v Abigroup Ltd (1998) 43 NSWLR 539 ; Abigroup Ltd v Akins (1997) 42 NSWLR 623 (Bainton J) — privilege not waived — not following Telstra Corp Ltd v Australis Media Holdings (No 1) (1997) 41 NSWLR 277 (McLelland CJ in Eq); Black & Decker Inc v Flymo Ltd [1991] 1 WLR 753 (privilege waived); Nilsen Industrial Electronics Pty Ltd v National Semiconductor Corp (1994) 48 FCR 337; BC9406031 (privilege not waived); Fairfield-Mabey Ltd v Shell UK Ltd [1989] 1 All ER 576 (privilege not waived). An alternate view is that litigation privilege does not attach to finalised proofs of evidence created by a party for the purpose of being served on the party’s opponent in litigation and when they are served on that opponent: ACCC v Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd (2009) 254 ALR 198; [2009] FCAFC 32; BC200901725 (finalised proofs of evidence filed and served on opponent — opponent ordered to list proofs of evidence to enable discovery in subsequent proceedings — Smoothdale No 2 Ltd v State Bank of South Australia (1995) 54 SASR 224; 180 LSJS 126 not followed).

Irrespective of whether exchanged statements are subject to privilege in such a situation, all statements that have been obtained from other parties should, until and unless they are admitted into evidence, be regarded as subject to an implied undertaking that they will not be used except for the purposes of the particular proceedings in which they were provided: Springfield Nominees Pty Ltd v Bridgelands Securities Ltd (1992) 36 FCR 217; 110 ALR 685; British Coal Corp v Dennis Rye Ltd (No 2) [1988] 3 All ER 816; [1988] 1 WLR 1113 (documents made available to a defendant in the course of criminal proceedings); Bell Group Ltd (in liq) v Westpac Banking Corp (1998) 86 FCR 215 at 220; 166 ALR 699 (liquidator required leave to use discovered documents and witness statements in examinations under the corporations legislation). Note the obiter comment in ACCC v Cadbury Schweppes Pty Ltd (2009) 254 ALR 198; [2009] FCAFC 32; BC200901725 at [97] that the implied undertaking did not preserve confidentiality in support of a claim for litigation privilege. The filing and service of the finalised proofs of evidence in this case was a complete waiver of such privilege as existed in the documents before their filing and service.

level.toc-caption: [31.4.25] Privilege and disclosure in relation to expert reports

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.4.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.20, r 31.28.

heading.title: Privilege and disclosure in relation to expert reports

p.text: In the absence of any specific direction (under UCPR r 31.20 ) and unless there is a contrary requirement in any Practice Note, expert reports must be served in accordance with UCPR r 31.28 . The question of privilege in relation to expert reports is dealt with in [31.28.40] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.5] r 31.5 Notice under s 67 or s 99 of the Evidence Act 1995 (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13D; DCR Part 28, rule 9A; LCR Part 23, rule 3A)

leg:heading.title: Notice under s 67 or s 99 of the Evidence Act 1995 (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13D; DCR Part 28, rule 9A; LCR Part 23, rule 3A)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, notice for the purposes of section 67 or 99 of the Evidence Act 1995 must be given:
in any case where the court by notice to the parties fixes a date for determining the date for hearing, not later than 21 days before the date fixed by that notice, and
in any other case where the place of hearing is a place other than Sydney, not later than 21 days before the first call-over held in respect of the sittings at that place, and
in any other case, not later than 21 days before the date on which the court determines the date for hearing.
Legislation cited in [31.5.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Div 2, SCR Pt 75 r 3(6).

This rule applies to criminal proceedings specified in the Third Schedule of the SCA (except cl (d) of that Schedule) and to proceedings in summary jurisdiction ( Div 2 of Pt 75 of the SCR) as if the time fixed for giving notice were not later than 21 days before the date fixed for hearing: SCR Pt 75 r 3(6) .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.6] r 31.6 Evidence on commission (cf SCR Part 36, rule 6; DCR Part 28, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Evidence on commission (cf SCR Part 36, rule 6; DCR Part 28, rule 7)

p.text: The court may permit a party to any proceedings the subject of an order under rule 24.3 (relating to the taking of evidence otherwise than at trial) to tender in the proceedings the evidence of a person examined under the order.
The evidence is not admissible in the proceedings if:
it appears to the satisfaction of the court that the person examined is in New South Wales and is able to attend the hearing, or
the evidence would not have been admissible had it been given orally at the hearing of the proceedings.
If it is in the interests of justice to do so, the court may exclude from the proceedings any evidence of the person examined even though the evidence is otherwise admissible.
Unless the court orders otherwise, evidence in any proceedings that a case falls within:
subrule (2)(a), or
section 8(2)(a) or 22(2)(a) of the Evidence on Commission Act 1995, or

section 9(2)(a) of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth, may be given by affidavit on information and belief, but the person making the affidavit must give the source of and ground for the information and belief.

The judicial officer presiding at the trial may make any necessary observations and findings as to demeanour and credibility of the person examined, and act on them for the determination of the issues at the trial, if:
the examination has been conducted by the same judicial officer, or
an audio-visual recording under rule 24.13 is tendered in evidence at the trial,
except where the trial is before a jury.
In this rule, evidence includes:
any document or thing produced at the examination, and
any answers made (whether in writing, or orally and reduced to writing) to any written interrogatories presented at the examination, and
any audio-visual recording made in accordance with rule 24.13.

The party who obtained the order for examination cannot be compelled to tender the transcript: Pearce v Pearce (1932) 49 WN (NSW) 177 . He or she may tender the transcript without the exhibits: Re Wilson (1891) 7 WN (NSW) 116. The opposing party may tender the transcript or exhibits in his or her case: Fisher v CHT Ltd [1965] 2 All ER 601; [1965] 1 WLR 1093 .

Where a defendant gives evidence before an examiner and the plaintiff leads evidence, at the trial, of conversations not put to the defendant, the evidence is admissible, but the defendant should have an adjournment to answer the material: Nyulasy v Rowan (1891) 12 ALT 193.
As to r 31.6(4), "information and belief", see [31.2.10] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.7] r 31.7 Foreign material (cf SCR Part 36, rule 6B)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, a party who adduces foreign material under section 24 or 32 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth as evidence:
must give at least 14 days’ written notice to each other active party of:
the intention to adduce evidence under that section, and
the nature of the foreign material, and
must adduce all relevant evidence available to that party:
as to whether the person who gave the testimony that is the subject of the foreign material is in Australia and is able to attend the hearing, and
if the foreign material is adduced under section 24 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth, of the matters to which section 25(2)(a) or (c) of that Act refer, and
if the foreign material is adduced under section 32 of the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth, of the matters to which section 33(2)(a) or (c) of that Act refer.
In this rule foreign material has the same meaning as it has in the Foreign Evidence Act 1994 of the Commonwealth.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.8] r 31.8 Earlier evidence in the same proceedings (cf SCR Part 36, rule 5; DCR Part 28, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Earlier evidence in the same proceedings (cf SCR Part 36, rule 5; DCR Part 28, rule 6)

p.text: Evidence taken at a trial with respect to a question that is ordered to be tried separately may be used in any subsequent trial in the same proceedings, saving all just exceptions and unless the court orders otherwise.

Evidence taken at a trial may be used for any subsequent trial for the assessment of damages or of the value of goods in the same proceedings, saving all just exceptions and unless the court orders otherwise.
Subject to subrules (1) and (2), evidence taken at a hearing may not be used as evidence in any subsequent hearing in the same proceedings except by leave of the court.

Apart from its unrestricted permission to use trial evidence on any subsequent assessment of damages, the rule otherwise permits the admission of testimonial evidence only “in relation to the proof of particular facts” and only with leave. As with the similarly worded provision in r 31.9, the scope of the permission thereby intended is not easy to understand. In Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) [2002] NSWSC 1193; BC200208078 Hamilton J agreed with the suggestion in Telnet Pty Ltd v Takapara Investments Pty Ltd (1994) 51 FCR 520 , that r 31.9(2) might be construed as requiring the party seeking leave to specify the particular facts sought to be proved.

level.toc-caption: [31.8.10] Scope of the discretion to grant leave

heading.title: Scope of the discretion to grant leave

p.text: Exercise of the discretion to grant leave under the present rule is, subject to two qualifications, likely to involve broadly similar considerations to those that inform the exercise of the discretion conferred by r 31.9 (to admit evidence taken in other proceedings). The first qualification is that because the present rule is confined to evidence taken earlier in the proceedings, it will not usually require considering the status of the parties, or their involvement when the evidence was given, although matters of that kind may be relevant in particular cases, for example where there has been a change in the parties or in the issues raised in the proceedings. The second qualification arises because s 75 of the Evidence Act 1995 permits hearsay evidence to be given on information as to source in relation to interlocutory matters. Consequently, the present rule may require special consideration where evidence of that kind is sought to be adduced: Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) [2002] NSWSC 1193; BC200208078 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.9] r 31.9 Earlier evidence in other proceedings (cf SCR Part 36, rule 7; DCR Part 28, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Earlier evidence in other proceedings (cf SCR Part 36, rule 7; DCR Part 28, rule 10)

p.text: In any proceedings, evidence taken, or an affidavit filed, in other proceedings may not be used as evidence, saving all just exceptions and unless the court orders otherwise.
Leave may not be granted under subrule (1) except to allow the evidence taken, or affidavit filed, in the other proceedings to be used in relation to the proof of particular facts.

The rule presupposes the general inadmissibility of testimonial evidence called by a party in previous proceedings: British Thomson-Houston Co Ltd v British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd [1924] 2 Ch 160 (oral expert evidence). Conversely, documents tendered by a party in previous proceedings, including formal admissions such as those in answers to interrogatories, are admissible against that party in subsequent proceedings: Brickell v Hulse (1837) 7 Ad & El 454; 112 ER 541; Gardner v Moult (1839) 10 Ad & El 464; 113 ER 176; Fleet v Perrins (1868) LR 3 QB 536; 9 B & S 575 (answers to interrogatories). The rule then permits the admission of testimonial evidence, with leave, but only “in relation to the proof of particular facts”. The scope of the permission thereby intended is not easy to understand. In Wentworth v Rogers (No 12) (1987) 9 NSWLR 400; BC8701295 , the Court of Appeal said that r 31.9(2) “precludes the evidence from being read on any issue at a trial except in relation to the proof of particular facts. But it is difficult to imagine what the evidence could be related to, other than proof of particular facts, except some matter of opinion.” In Telnet Pty Ltd v Takapara Investments Pty Ltd (1994) 51 FCR 520 , Olney J suggested that r 31.9(2) might be construed as requiring the party seeking leave to specify the particular facts sought to be proved — a suggestion implicitly accepted in Complete Technology Pty Ltd v Toshiba (Aust) Pty Ltd (1994) 53 FCR 125 at 132; 124 ALR 493; BC9405908 and Lewis v Nortex Pty Ltd (in liq) [2002] NSWSC 1193; BC200208078 .

level.toc-caption: [31.9.10] Scope of the discretion to grant leave

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.9.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 69.

heading.title: Scope of the discretion to grant leave

p.text: In order to be within the rule the evidence—
must have been in proceedings between the same parties or their privies,
must be otherwise admissible, and

must go to the same fact situation in each set of proceedings although the relief sought may differ: Llanover v Homfray (1881) 19 Ch D 224 at 230 ; Brown v White (1876) 24 WR 456 ; Simmons v London Joint Stock Bank (1890) 62 LT 427 at 429 ; Re Borgho's Estate [1896] 1 Ir R 274.

The rule does not permit the court to grant leave to use the evidence of witnesses in other proceedings between other parties on a similar issue: Printing Telegraph and Construction Co of Agents AGE & Havas Ltd v Drucker [1894] 2 QB 801. Thus the rule does not permit the admission into evidence of depositions in a coroner's court: Bird v Keep [1918] 2 KB 692; (1918) 34 TLR 513 ; Barrett v Cohen [1921] 2 KB 461. However, it may not be necessary to rely upon the rule if the transcript is otherwise admissible under s 69 of the Evidence Act 1995: Weir v Vallis (NSWSC, Wood J, No 13020/90, 30 October 1993, unreported, BC9001809).

Pleadings are generally inadmissible to establish an admission against the party filing them, or the truth of the matters alleged: Boileau v Rutlin (1848) 2 LJ Ex 665; 154 ER 657; McKinlay v North Australian Co (1869) 3 SALR 135 at 139; Perry v Woolcock [1917] SALR 216 ; Austin v Austin [1905] VLR 564 at 566; (1905) 11 ALR 337 ; Kleeners Pty Ltd v Lee Tim (1959) 78 WN (NSW) 746 at 747 ; British Thomson-Houston Co Ltd v British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd [1924] 1 Ch 203 on appeal British Thomson-Houston Co Ltd v British Insulated and Helsby Cables Ltd [1924] 2 Ch 160. The inadmissibility of the pleadings derives from their character as allegations, and it has been accepted by the High Court that an assertion made in a pleading does not constitute an admission, especially in the case of a defence: Laws v Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (1990) 170 CLR 70; 93 ALR 435; BC9002913 . The general inadmissibility of pleadings may be subject to some qualification in the light of the requirement for verification imposed by r 14.22–r 14.24: see Singleton v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 38 at 50 where David Hunt J declined to follow the older authorities. But there is a conceptual distinction between a formal admission and an assertion, even one in respect of which a party deposes to belief in its truth. Accordingly, in Stohl Aviation v Electrum Finance Pty Ltd (1984) 5 FCR 187; 56 ALR 716 Jenkinson J refused to follow Singleton v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd, above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.10] r 31.10 Plans, photographs and models (cf SCR Part 14, rule 2, Part 36, rule 8; DCR Part 28, rule 11; LCR Part 23, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Plans, photographs and models (cf SCR Part 14, rule 2, Part 36, rule 8; DCR Part 28, rule 11; LCR Part 23, rule 4)

p.text: At least 7 days before the commencement of a hearing, a party who intends to tender any plan, photograph, audio-visual recording or model at the hearing must give the other parties an opportunity to inspect it and to agree to its admission without proof.
[subr (1) am Amendment 49 of 2011 r 3(1), effective 18 November 2011]
A party who fails to comply with subrule (1) may not tender the plan, photograph, audio-visual recording or model in evidence except:
in the case of a prescribed item — where the court is satisfied that the party had a legitimate forensic purpose for not giving the other parties an opportunity to inspect the item, or
in any other case — by leave of the court.
[subr (2) subst Amendment 49 of 2011 r 3(2), effective 18 November 2011]
This rule does not apply to any proceedings entered, or intended to be entered, in:
the Commercial List or the Technology and Construction List in the Supreme Court, or
the Commercial List or the Construction List in the District Court.
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[7], effective 7 July 2006]
In this rule:
includes a sound recording or a record of moving images (or both) whether stored on film, audio or video tape, digitally, electronically or by any other means.

means a photograph or audio-visual recording that was made or obtained in connection with the relevant proceedings, by or at the request of a party, for the purpose of testing the credibility of a witness at the hearing.
[subr (4) insrt Amendment 49 of 2011 r 3(1), effective 18 November 2011]
[r 31.10 am Amendment 10 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[6], effective 7 July 2006]
Legislation cited in [31.10.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 s 21.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 17.5(2), r 21.2, r 21.6, r 33.8.

Apart from the present rule, plans, drawings, photographs and any form of audio or audio visual recording, all fall within the definition of “document” in s 21 of the Interpretation Act 1987 and are discoverable in accordance with UCPR r 21.2 (order for discovery) and UCPR r 21.6 (continuing discovery). Models do not themselves fall within the definition of “document”, but could be made the subject of an order for inspection under UCPR r 33.8 . Where “documents” have been discovered, and inspection allowed, the discovering party is entitled to the benefit of the implied admissions provided for in UCPR r 17.5(2) — unless the inspecting party provides a relevant contrary notice.

level.toc-caption: [31.10.10] Plans, photographs, recordings and models — evidentiary aids

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.10.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 31.20, 31.21, r 31.4.

heading.title: Plans, photographs, recordings and models — evidentiary aids

p.text: Plans, photographs, audio visual recordings and models may be useful aids in understanding aspects of the evidence that cannot be verbally communicated as readily, or as effectively, in the courtroom. Where “plans, photographs, recordings and models” are of this kind, a mere failure of timely compliance with the disclosure requirements of the present rule should rarely be sanctioned by rejection at the hearing – at least in the absence of any question of their accuracy and reliability. Sometimes “plans, photographs, recordings and models” may require expert interpretation and explanation – and evidence to that effect is admissible in principle: Ready Mixed Concrete Pty Ltd v Papua New Guinea [1981] PNG LR 396 at 401 per Miles J (expert evidence about the contents of official aerial photographs and x-rays — court is required to reach its own conclusion on the matters of fact to which the photographs relate). In these instances the additional evidence will ordinarily be the subject of either a witness statement under UCPR r 31.4 or an expert report under UCPR rr 31.20 and 31.21 . Where those rules apply, and have been complied with, it would again rarely be appropriate to thereafter exclude the tender of related “plans, photographs, recordings and models” merely because of a lack of timely compliance with the present rule. Of course late disclosure may justify exclusion of “plans, photographs, recordings and models” if their accuracy, relevance is not otherwise sufficiently established.

level.toc-caption: [31.10.15] Photographs and recordings — discretion to withhold from production or inspection

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.10.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56.

heading.title: Photographs and recordings — discretion to withhold from production or inspection

p.text: Many UCP provisions encourage pre-trial disclosure as an important means of giving effect to the “overriding purpose” provided for in CPA s 56 . However the “leave” exclusion in the present rule implicitly contemplates the deliberate withholding of “plans, photographs and models” from an opposing party. The occasions when leave of that kind might properly be given are few, and are confined to instances where late disclosure has been thought to be a necessary means of testing evidence of doubtful veracity: Halpin v Lumley General Insurance Ltd (2009) 261 ALR 741; [2009] NSWCA 372; BC200910469 at [89]–[94] and [97]–[101]; and see [21.5.48] .

The most common instance in which non-disclosure of this kind has been thought to be appropriate concerns the use of surveillance film in personal injury proceedings where there is an issue about a plaintiff’s good faith: Naylor v Preston Area Health Authority [1987] 1 WLR 958 at 967 and 973–4; McGuinness v Kellog Co of GB Ltd [1988] 2 All ER 902 ; and see [21.5.48] . Some cases have held that non-disclosure may be a necessary and even an essential aspect of “procedural fairness”: Australian Postal Commission v Hayes (1989) 23 FCR 320 ; Robbins v Harbord (1994) 62 SASR 229 ; BHP Pty Co Ltd v Mason (1996) 67 SASR 456 . It is doubtful whether the potential justification for non-disclosure can really be put as a matter of a defendant’s entitlement to procedural fairness: Re Applicant and Deputy Commissioner of Taxation (1995) 41 ALD 683 ; Oliveri v Administrative Appeals Tribunal (1997) 50 ALD 190 at 194 ; Kingham v Cole (2002) 76 ALD 389 at [21]–[26] (the argument elevates a useful forensic technique to the status of a mandatory legal rule). Nevertheless, the potential justification for withholding inspection of this kind of material is explicitly contemplated in UCPR r 31.10(2). And consistent that potential justification there is a recognised suggested practice for ex parte applications to obtain leave under the present rule: McGuinness v Kellogg Co of GB Ltd [1988] 2 All ER 902 at 905; [1988] 1 WLR 913 (supporting affidavit and specific identification of the material being withheld).

The present rule makes clear however, that disclosure is the ordinary course and that the granting of ex parte leave, and the consequential delayed disclosure of material evidence, involves a departure from the usually desirable conduct of proceedings. Many of the reported cases emphasise that particular justification is required for an order granting leave. Typically the more recent cases doubt that the surprise involved in late disclosure is a useful means of either revealing or discouraging exaggerated or dishonest evidence: Khan v Armaguard Ltd [1994] 1 WLR 1204 at 1211 . At the same time they point out the significant injustice that delayed disclosure may occasion to a plaintiff — including the inability to recollect material explanatory evidence, comparative disadvantage in attempting to settle the proceedings and possible inability to obtain relevant supporting medical evidence. These reservations against the unwarranted use of the discretion to permit “non-disclosure” of surveillance film are persuasively expressed in Boyes v Colins (2000) 23 WAR 123 especially 139-146; Brown v Metro Meat International Ltd [2000] WACA 123 at [21]–[24]. Those judgments point out both the significant disadvantages that may accrue to a plaintiff as a result of late disclosure, and the highly problematical basis for the argument that delayed courtroom disclosure is likely to contribute to the accuracy of a plaintiff’s actual evidence.

level.toc-caption: [31.10.20] Refusal of leave — does not require production or inspection

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.10.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 31.21, 31.22.

heading.title: Refusal of leave — does not require production or inspection

p.text: Refusal of leave under the present rule does not automatically oblige the unsuccessful party to produce the contentious plan, photograph, recording or model for inspection. Photographs and recordings, especially surveillance film, obtained for the purpose of the proceedings will be likely to be subject to client legal, or litigation, privilege (Boyes v Colins (2000) 23 WAR 123 ) and not amenable to a direct order for production: Victoria v Davies (2003) 6 VLR 245; [2003] VSCA 65; BC200302798 . An indirect disclosure obligation may arise either because of the present rule or because of the effect of any direction made for the service of witness statements and expert’s reports: see UCPR rr 31.21 and 31.22 . Notwithstanding the conditional disclosure obligations that so arise, and effectively make prior disclosure of the “plan, photograph, recording or model” a pre-condition of its admissibility, it was obliquely suggested in Australian Postal Corporation v Bessey [2001] 32 AAR 508 at [18] and [19] that this could not operate to preclude a cross-examiner from merely “showing” the film to a witness in the course of their cross-examination.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.11] r 31.11 Production of court documents (cf SCR Part 36, rule 10; DCR Part 28, rule 13; LCR Part 23, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Production of court documents (cf SCR Part 36, rule 10; DCR Part 28, rule 13; LCR Part 23, rule 6)

p.text: Unless the court orders otherwise, the registrar must produce to the court any document in the registrar’s custody that, by notice in writing, any party to proceedings requests the registrar to produce to the court for the purposes of the proceedings.
Legislation cited in [31.11.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999.

Access to documents in court files is subject to the control of the court registrar. In both the Supreme Court (Practice Note SC Gen 2, reproduced at [SC Gen 2] in Vol 2) and the District Court (Practice Note DC (Civil) 11, reproduced at [DC (Civil) 11] in Vol 2) the procedures for obtaining access to court files are the subject of specific provisions in practice notes. However, the Practice Note procedures are not the exclusive procedure for permitting access. The court retains an incidental power to permit access to evidentiary material concerning current proceedings: Hammond v Scheinberg (2001) 52 NSWLR 49 at 52; [2001] NSWSC 568; BC200103695 (access to affidavit evidence in current proceedings). The fundamental principle is that the discretion should be exercised consistently with upholding the paramount importance of maintaining a transparent and accessible process of justice: Eisa Ltd v Brady [2000] NSWSC 929; BC200005827 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich (2001) 51 NSWLR 643; 38 ACSR 251; [2001] NSWSC 496; BC200103090 . In applying that principle, the exercise of the discretion to grant access will require consideration of the status of the proceedings and the nature of the information to which access is sought. Either of these considerations may be determinative in particular circumstances. Consequently, access will normally be granted to material that has already been used as evidence in the final public hearing of the proceedings. Where access is sought to information used in connection with obtaining ex parte orders (where the evidence is necessarily untested and may also be commercially sensitive) the nature of the proceedings, and the result of the ex parte application, may favour disclosure of substantial parts of the information — despite the risks of inaccuracy and bias inherent in untested information proffered solely by one party to proceedings: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Rich, above, (limited ex parte orders made in connection with a highly publicised public company failure). Where the information solely relates to preparatory interlocutory matters, access to the material will only be granted in exceptional circumstances. The discretion does not permit inspection of filed documents to which client legal privilege applies: Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Markets Ltd [2004] NSWSC 40; BC200400230 (affidavits filed as required by the Supreme Court (Corporations) Rules 1999 ).

level.toc-caption: [31.11.10] Production of documents to a non-party

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.11.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 71.

heading.title: Production of documents to a non-party

p.text: The procedure for obtaining access formerly involved a formal motion (and is discussed in Lunn v Savage; Ex parte Cmr of Police (NSWSC, Young J, No 3047/89, 30 March 1995, unreported, BC9504444)). It is now governed by the court practice notes (see Supreme Court Practice Note SC Gen 2, reproduced at [SC Gen 2] in Vol 2 and District Court Practice Note DC (Civil) 11, reproduced at [DC (Civil) 11] in Vol 2), which explain the normal access arrangements and provide a simple form to be used for applications to a registrar. Where the application is within the circumstances contemplated by the practice notes, no formal application, for example, by notice of motion, will be required and a request may be made to the appropriate registrar. Depending on the nature of the proceedings, and the particular documents to which access is sought, and perhaps also depending on the identity of the applicant, at least three different public interests may fall to be considered: (a) the maintenance of a transparent and accessible system of justice; (b) the due and orderly conduct of investigations by law enforcement agencies; and (c) maintenance of the fundamental privilege against self-incrimination, see: Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Michalik [2004] NSWSC 966; BC200406857 (application by journalist for access to affidavits of ASIC investigator). While the first of these interests is consistent with the principle of open justice implicit in CPA s 71 , that principle does not operate to confer a right of access to court documents relating to proceedings between third parties: John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd v Ryde Local Court (2005) 62 NSWLR 512; 220 ALR 248; [2005] NSWCA 101; BC200501968 at [31] (media organisation seeking access to Local Court file in quasi criminal proceedings against a magistrate — application refused): Cosoff v Rydon [2007] NSWSC 388; BC200702910 (journalist’s application for access — confidential commercial information — ongoing litigation — application refused). Where an application raises issues likely to be contentious a judge may give notice of the application to the parties to give them an opportunity to be heard.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.12] r 31.12 Proof of court documents (cf SCR Part 36, rule 9; DCR Part 28, rule 12; LCR Part 23, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Proof of court documents (cf SCR Part 36, rule 9; DCR Part 28, rule 12; LCR Part 23, rule 5)

p.text: A document purporting to be marked with the seal of any court or tribunal is admissible in evidence without further proof.
For the purposes of subrule (1) , it is sufficient that only the first page of a document consisting of multiple pages is marked with the seal.
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 46 of 2011 Sch 1[3], effective 9 September 2011]
[r 31.12 am Amendment 46 of 2011 Sch 1[3], effective 9 September 2011]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.13] r 31.13 Unstamped documents: arrangements under section 304 of the Duties Act 1997 (cf SCR Part 36, rule 10B)

leg:heading.title: Unstamped documents: arrangements under section 304 of the Duties Act 1997 (cf SCR Part 36, rule 10B)

p.text: The "usual undertaking by person liable" if given to the court by a party in relation to an instrument referred to in section 304(2) of the Duties Act 1997 is an undertaking that the party will, within a time specified by the court, transmit the instrument to the Chief Commissioner of State Revenue.

The "usual undertaking by person not liable" if given to the court by a party in relation to an instrument referred to in section 304(2) of the Duties Act 1997 is an undertaking that the party will, within a time specified by the court, forward to the Chief Commissioner of State Revenue the name and address of the person liable to pay duty on the instrument under that Act together with the instrument.

level.toc-caption: [31.13.5] Admissibility and effect of unstamped documents

heading.title: Admissibility and effect of unstamped documents

p.text: Section 304(1) of the Duties Act 1997 conditionally precludes the receipt of unstamped documents into evidence. The prohibition does not apply if the documents are admitted in accordance with arrangements approved under s 304(2) of the Duties Act. The “usual undertaking” referred to in the present rule constitutes an approved arrangement for the purposes of the subsection. If a document is received into evidence, notwithstanding non-compliance with s 304, and forms the basis of a subsequent judgment or order, the parties rights under the unstamped document merge in the judgment or order and are enforceable notwithstanding the non-compliance: McKensey v Hewitt (2004) 61 NSWLR 54; [2004] NSWSC 636; BC200404573 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.14] r 31.14 Unstamped documents: undertaking in respect of section 29 of the Stamp Duties Act 1920 (cf SCR Part 36, rule 10A; DCR Part 28, rule 13A)

leg:heading.title: Unstamped documents: undertaking in respect of section 29 of the Stamp Duties Act 1920 (cf SCR Part 36, rule 10A; DCR Part 28, rule 13A)

p.text: The “solicitor’s usual undertaking as to stamp duty”, if given to the court by a solicitor in relation to an instrument referred to in section 29 of the Stamp Duties Act 1920, or an unexecuted copy referred to in that section, is an undertaking that the solicitor will cause the instrument or copy to be presented to the Chief Commissioner of State Revenue for assessment in accordance with that Act and cause any duty and fine to which the instrument or copy is liable to be paid.

The "party’s usual undertaking as to stamp duty", if given to the court by a party in relation to an instrument referred to in section 29(4) of the Stamp Duties Act 1920, is an undertaking that the party will, within 28 days, inform the Chief Commissioner of State Revenue of the name of the person primarily liable to duty in respect of the instrument and lodge the instrument or a copy of the instrument with the Chief Commissioner.

level.toc-caption: [31.14.5] Section 29 of the Stamp Duties Act 1920

p.text: Legislation cited in [31.14.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Stamp Duties Act 1920 s 29.

heading.title: Section 29 of the Stamp Duties Act 1920

p.text: Section 29 of the Stamp Duties Act 1920 precludes an instrument executed in NSW or relating to property or anything done in NSW from being pleaded or given in evidence or admitted unless stamped. The Stamp Duties Act 1920 applies to an instrument first executed or relating to applicable transactions or property in NSW before 1 July 1998. Instruments first executed on or from 1 July 1998 are subject to s 304 of the Duties Act 1997: see above at [31.13.5] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.15] r 31.15 Evidence of consent to act as tutor, trustee, receiver or other office (cf SCR Part 36, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Evidence of consent to act as tutor, trustee, receiver or other office (cf SCR Part 36, rule 11)

p.text: A document:

purporting to contain a person’s written consent to act as tutor of a person under legal incapacity, to act as trustee, to act as receiver or to act in any other office on appointment by the court, and
purporting to have been duly executed and authenticated,
is evidence of the consent.
A document is duly executed and authenticated for the purposes of subrule (1):
in the case of a consenting person who is a natural person, if the document is signed by the consenting person and the signature is verified by some other person, or
in the case of a consenting person that is a corporation, if the seal of the corporation is affixed to the document in accordance with the law regulating the use of the seal.
Legislation cited in [31.15.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 Form 80.
Precedents for forms of consent and verification are—
for a “tutor”: precedent 25(4) in Neville and Ashe, Equity Proceedings with Precedents (NSW);
for a “trustee”: precedent 12(8) in Neville and Ashe;
for a “receiver”: precedent 12(8) in Neville and Ashe.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.16] r 31.16 Evidence of published research concerning maintenance of children (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13E)

leg:heading.title: Evidence of published research concerning maintenance of children (cf SCR Part 36, rule 13E)

p.text: If the proper needs of a minor are relevant, the court may have regard, to the extent to which it considers appropriate, to any relevant findings of published research in relation to the maintenance of minors.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 31.16A] r 31.16A Return of exhibits (cf SCR Part 75, rule 3I)

leg:heading.title: Return of exhibits (cf SCR Part 75, rule 3I)

p.text: Where proceedings have been concluded and:
4 months have expired since the conclusion, and
there is no undisposed of appeal, or application for leave to appeal, in respect of the proceedings,
the registrar may, unless the court otherwise orders, return any exhibit in the proceedings still in the custody of the registrar by forwarding it to the party from whom it was received.
[r 31.16A insrt Amendment 23 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[8], effective 7 November 2008]

level.toc-caption: [31.16A.5] Return of exhibits and material produced to the court

heading.title: Return of exhibits and material produced to the court

p.text: The Supreme Court’s practice, following the introduction of Practice Note SC Gen 18 — “Production of and access to subpoenaed material and returning exhibits and subpoenaed material in civil proceedings” is to order the return of all exhibits and produced documents following the determination of the proceedings. If the material has been provided as copies, it may be destroyed: see UCPR r 33.10(5). If the material has been provided in an electronic format, the material may be deleted or erased: see Practice Note SC Gen 18 cl 21.
